body.content:
You can fly most flags, including the Union Flag (also called the Union Jack), without getting permission or 'consent' from the council. Some flags have restrictions on how and where they can be flown.

All flags must:

- be in keeping with the appearance and character of where they're flown
- be flown with the permission of the site owner 
- not impact any official road, rail, waterway or aircraft signs
- be placed in a safe location and be able to be removed safely

^There are specific days [when the Union Flag must be flown on government buildings](/designated-days-for-union-flag-flying). However, the flag can also be flown on any other days.^

parts.title: Flags you can fly without permission

body.content:
You don't need permission to fly any number of the following flags:

- the Union Flag (also called the Union Jack) or the individual flags of England, Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland
- any country’s national flag, civil ensign or civil air ensign
- the flag of any island, county, district, borough, burgh, parish, city, town or village within the UK
- the flag of the Black Country, East Anglia, Wessex, any Part of Lincolnshire, any Riding of Yorkshire or any historic county within the UK
- any flag of Her Majesty’s forces or the Armed Forces Day flag
- the flags of Saint David or Saint Patrick
- the flag of the Commonwealth, the European Union, the United Nations or any other international organisation the UK belongs to
- the flag of any administrative area within any country outside the UK

You must not display anything other than the flags (eg adverts), but you can attach a black ribbon to the flagpole if you're unable to fly the flag at half-mast. 

%You may need [planning permission](/anning-permission-england-wales) to erect a flagpole.%

  • the flag of the Black Country, East Anglia, Wessex, any Part of Lincolnshire, any Riding of Yorkshire or any historic county within the UK
  • any flag of Her Majesty’s forces or the Armed Forces Day flag
  • the flags of Saint David or Saint Patrick
  • the flag of the Commonwealth, the European Union, the United Nations or any other international organisation the UK belongs to

You must not display anything other than the flags (eg adverts), but you can attach a black ribbon to the flagpole if you’re unable to fly the flag at half-mast.

You can fly the following flags without permission as long as you follow certain restrictions:

- house flags to display the name, emblem, device or trademark of the company or person occupying the building
- flags for a specific event that is taking place in the building
- sports club flags (as long as they don't include sponsorship logos)
- the horizontal striped rainbow flag (the Pride Flag)
- award schemes such as Eco-Schools, Queens Awards for Enterprise and Investors in People 

The restrictions depend on whether the flag is flown:

- from a vertical flagpole on the roof of a building
- from a flagpole that projects from the side of a building (ie it comes out at an angle) 
- in the grounds of a building 

You must [contact the local council](/find-your-local-council) to find out if you can fly any other type of flag or a flag that doesn't meet any of the restrictions.

%You may need [planning permission](/planning-permission-england-wales) to erect a flagpole.%

##How many flags you can fly

You can do 1 of the following without applying for permission.

You can fly 1 flag from the roof of a building on a vertical flagpole, from the side of a building on a projected flagpole, from a building (from the roof or the side), and 1 flag within the grounds of a building.

Or you can fly 2 flags from a building, 1 from the roof and 1 from side, or fly 2 flags within the grounds of a building.

##Flags on the roof of a building

There are no restrictions on the size of the flag, or the size of any characters or symbols on the flag, except in a 'controlled area' or 'area of special control'.

Controlled areas include areas of outstanding natural beauty, the Broads, conservation areas or a National Park. Flags in these areas can have characters or symbols no taller than 75cm. 

Areas of special control are decided by local councils. Flags these areas can have characters or symbols no taller 30cm. 

##Flags on the side of a building 

Flags on a projecting flagpole from the side of a building must be no larger than 2 square meters. There are no restrictions on the size of any characters on the flag.

You'll need to get permission for the [local council](/find-your-local-council) to fly a flag from the side of a building in a controlled area.

##Flags within the grounds of a building

Flagpoles must be no taller than 4.6 meters if they're within the grounds of a building. There are no restrictions on the size of the flag.
